_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Tested the float switches for the Intercooler and Low Temperature Recirculator, and high/low pressure cutouts for the booster compressors.
_prev_prog_3.Description: Ammonia refrigeration system for cold and freezer storage of food products.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



Turlock Cold Storage, located in Turlock, California, utilizes refrigeration for cold and freezer storage of food products.



Senior management at Turlock Cold Storage is not only committed to offer superior service, but also to maintaining a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities.  Senior management as well as Safety Coordinators administer the facility's safety and environmental policies and programs. These programs include but are not limited to forklift safety, hazard communications, lockout/tagout, Hazardous Materials Emergency Business Plan, employee safety manuals, manufacturers documentation, Emergency Response, as well as the Risk Management Plan. 



Turlock Cold Storage has coordinated emergency response efforts with Stanislaus County. In the case of an ammonia-related emergency, it is the policy of Turlock Cold Storage to evacuate employees and to notify the fire department/HazMat team to respond to the emergency. Facility refrigeration operators will be available for guidance and assistance.



The majority of the equipment is located inside the engine room. The system is a closed loop refrigeration system, similar to a residential refrigerator. There are no emissions or planned releases of ammonia.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



The Turlock Cold Storage facility is located at 107 South Kilroy Road in Turlock, California.  The facility is approximately 0.2 miles west of State Highway 99, situated at the southwest corner of the intersection created by South Kilroy and West Main Street. The area immediately surrounding the facility is rural with commercial areas.  



The primary business of Turlock Cold Storage is to provide refrigeration for cold and freezer storage of food products. In order to conduct operations, the facility maintains a refrigeration system containing approximately 19,290 pou

nds of anhydrous ammonia, a regulated substance.  The refrigeration system, consisting of piping, valves, and equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, and then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration for the storage of various food products.  Typical operating conditions range from 0 psig on the low pressure side of the system, 5 psig on the intermediate side, to 135 psig on the high side.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



In order to operate the ammonia refrigeration system, the facility complies with the Cal-OES California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.



Administrative Measures: The facility operates in accordance with the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines and standards including the following:



?    IIAR Bulletin 107, "Suggested Safety and Operating Procedures When Making Ammonia Refrigeration Tie ins"

?    IIAR Bulletin 109, "Minimum Safety Criteria for a Safe Ammonia Refrigeration System"

?    IIAR Bulletin 110, "Startup, Inspection, and Maintenance of Ammonia Refrigeration Systems"

?    IIAR, "A Guide to Good Practices for the Operation of an Ammonia Refrigeration System"



The Turlock Cold Storage ammonia refrigeration system has many safety features.  Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system. Turlock Cold Storage facility has implemented a Process Safety Management program for compliance with the Cal-OSHA regulation. It is important to note that the refrigeration system has been designed with several safety features to prevent the accidental release of ammonia. For example, the compressors are equipped with safety mechanisms that will cause the units to shut down if operating conditions exceed designated safety limits.  Also, level indicators, alarms, and switches are

installed in key points within the system to monitor the supply of liquid ammonia and to ensure that a vessel is not overfilled.  Pressure relief valves on all pressure vessels protect the equipment from overpressurization.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



EPA's RMP regulation defines "accident" as the following:



"The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process.



The release must have caused at least one of the following:



?    On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (?68.42(a)); or

?    Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (?68.42(a))."



Based on the above definition and an investigation into the facility's accident history conducted at the time of the Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation study (April 23, 2014), there have been no significant releases of ammonia that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds in the last five years (April 2009 - April 2014). In addition, there have been no releases meeting the accident criteria described above or "near misses" that warranted an internal incident investigation.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The facility has an Emergency Action Plan (plan) in effect.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:  



?    save lives;

?    minimize and avoid injuries;

?    protect the environment; and

?    minimize property damage.



The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year. This Plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the Process Safety Management regulations.  



In the event of a spill, release, near miss, or threatened release involving ammonia, the event will be repor

ted to the supervisor in whose area the incident occurred. The supervisor will in turn report to the Plant Manager and/or Chief Engineer. The Plant Manager and/or Chief Engineer will immediately determine the quantity of the release and, if deemed necessary, notify the appropriate authorities and agencies. They will also determine whether the system requires shut down.



If evacuation of the facility is necessary, plant personnel will vacate the facility according to evacuation routes outlined in Section15 of the Sierra Pacific Emergency Response Plan and Procedures. Emergency assembly area locations are to the north of the facility, and are discussed in the same section of the Emergency Response Plan and Procedures. The Emergency Response Team and area supervisors are the responsible parties for ensuring all employees are evacuated safely. They are also responsible for ensuring all employees evacuate to the designated rendezvous point.



Notification of evacuation will be provided in the form of an emergency whistle, or "disaster alarm". Three (3) short blasts of the disaster alarm, followed by a pause, followed by three more short blasts will signify work area evacuation. The emergency coordinator is responsible for sounding the disaster alarm.



In the event the emergency coordinator is unavailable, the emergency coordinator alternate will become responsible for sounding the disaster alarm. If evacuation of the entire facility is necessary, designated emergency action personnel will coordinate the movement of employees to the appropriate assembly area or rendezvous point. Emergency response drills involving all facility personnel are performed on an annual basis. This ensures that employees are familiar with evacuation routes from the facility.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



A Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation was conducted on April 23rd, 2014. The report includes the results from the following two elements: 1) the Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) st

udy and 2) a site inspection. This study was performed to define potential hazards associated with operational deviations of the ammonia system. The study generated mitigation measures (recommendations) to improve safety at the Turlock Cold Storage facility located in Turlock, California.  The mitigation measures include additional training, key maintenance related tests/inspection, and enhanced emergency response policies and procedures.  The Turlock Cold Storage facility is planning to complete several items, including the recommendations, over the next year, as a continual effort to provide a safe work environment for their employees.  These changes include the following items:



1. Continue to train all employees in the facility Safety Plan/Programs.



2. Continue to have employee involvement in Safety Plan Development.



3. Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.



4. Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.
